documents.commentText:
My name is Danny Poit. I am 35 years old and a father, husband, homeowner, and tax-paying citizen. I work for a tech company creating training materials and assisting new accounts with migrating their services. I am also a composer of music for film, video games, advertising, and other media. I have a Bachelors degree from Berklee College of Music where I graduated Summa Cum Laude.

I am a recovering opioid addict, and when I take kratom, I do not feel any urges to use opioids whatsoever. It is also a tremendous relief for my social anxiety, which I have suffered from for over 20 years, and for mild-to-moderate sciatic pain. While opioids certainly made me feel high and gave me stronger pain relief, they just didn't help me feel good about myself in the way kratom does. Opioids feel intoxicating; I don't feel like myself on them. Also, I have to keep increasing my dose on opioids and am always thinking about ways to get more, despite the disastrous consequences I am putting myself and my family at risk for.

With kratom, I don't want to get high anymore. Kratom makes me feel better about myself without feeling high. According to a recent survey of over 6,000 kratom users, only 2% believe you can get high from kratom (www.painnewsnetwork.org/stories/2016/9/18/kratom-users-say-ban-will-lead-to-more-drug-abuse). Kratom allows me to do the things I need to do  be a father, be a husband, get my work done, be more social, and I don't feel like I need more of it. I can be okay with taking just enough to feel its subtle effects and live my life without obsessing over it. There is a mild physical dependency that develops after using it daily for a few weeks, but I believe the physical dependency is comparable to a large coffee habit. By taking kratom, I feel as though I am retraining my brain to be less of an addict. It is a wonderful plant, and it has prevented me from relapsing and destroying my life.

In the DEAs notice of its intent to schedule kratom, it was stated that there have been 15 kratom-related deaths in the past two years, but as NPR has reported, fourteen of the 15 people also had other drugs or illegal substances in their systems (www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2016/09/12/493295493/kratom-advocates-speak-out-against-proposed-government-ban). There is not one recorded death in the US where the cause was only kratom. With this in mind, I do not believe kratom qualifies as an imminent hazard to public safety, as the DEA described.

Another statistic that was mentioned was that 660 calls were made to poison control centers regarding kratom over the past five years. Taken out of context, this may sound like a lot, but in reality this is a small amount of calls, especially when compared to opioid painkillers or even over-the-counter painkillers such as Tylenol. Vitamins receive more calls to US poison control centers per year than kratom, and they are generally considered extremely safe (https://aapcc.s3.amazonaws.com/pdfs/annual_reports/2014_AAPCC_NPDS_Annual_Report.pdf).

I appreciate that the DEA recognized that kratom is not suitable for emergency placement onto Schedule I and has withdrawn their intent to do so. However, I believe placing kratom into any schedule of the Controlled Substances Act would be a huge mistake and could be detrimental to many citizens and business in this country. If scheduled, many Americans who are using kratom safely and responsibly will lose access to it immediately. Some will return to harder drugs and may overdose and die.

If the DEA still intends to schedule kratom, the onus will be on them to demonstrate the danger of kratom to the public to warrant scheduling. Given the relative safety of kratom, as evidenced by the data and medical studies currently available, and numerous accounts of people who are currently using it, I believe it is clear that scheduling kratom is not the appropriate course of action. Also, as a controlled substance, research into kratom would become difficult for doctors and scientists to pursue, and we may never know the true potential of this plant to help America's opioid addicts and chronic pain sufferers.

One thing the DEA and kratom community agree on is that further research is needed on this plant and its alkaloids. The vast majority of kratom users are in favor of regulation by the FDA as a dietary supplement. We don't want to see it in gas stations and smoke shops, advertised as a legal high. We don't want it sold to minors. We want better testing and standards for alkaloid content, dosage, and labeling. But given the plants current widespread use by responsible adults and safety record, placing it onto any schedule of the Controlled Substances Act is not warranted. Kratom should remain legal without a prescription and be further researched and regulated by the FDA.

To Whom it May Concern,

I am a 43 y/o male.  I am a physical therapist and have worked in healthcare for my entire adult career.  This background has helped me to research my own condition and be able to read scientific journals and other medical texts that pertain to my condition. 

Since adolescence I have had Periodic Limb Movement Disorder, which is a cousin of Restless Legs Syndrome- essentially I have frequent involuntary movements at night that interfere with my ability to get restful sleep.  These movements were first detected by a formal sleep study when I was 17 years old.  At that time the treatment offered was klonopin which I tried; however, it resulted in greater fatigue during the day; therefore, I stopped it.  Over the next 18 or so  years I managed my fatigue coffee and intermittently used  Ambien- which only helped a little. 

In my late 30's I consulted with another sleep doctor at Harvard and had another sleep study which again showed frequent involuntary movements.  I was given Mirapex and Provigil to help manage the fatigue.  This cocktail proved to be extremely effective and eventually I didn't even need the Provigil as the Mirapex was so effective in controlling my movements. 
Unfortunately,  after about 4 or 5 years the Mirapex stopped working so well.  I believe that I was beginning to have what is called "Augmentation" from the Mirapex, which is a known side effect of the dopamine agonists.  My sleep and movements worsened and I went back to see the sleep specialist who then tried a variety of other pharmaceuticals,  (Horizant, Gabapentin, Restoril), Dilautid, and Morhpine).  I found that most of these pharmaceuticals didn't control the movements very well and the side effects were very difficult to manage-  a hangover in the morning, fatigue, depression, irritability, and overall compromised executive function.  The opiates initially worked well but after a couple of weeks they didn't work well.  Both my doctor and I were hesitant to increase the dose given the issues with tolerance and dependence.

At this point I was getting desperate I was having difficulty working and the fatigue made it difficult to live a normal life.  I started researching online and stumbled a well-known forum for Restless Legs and that is where I first learned about Kratom.  I did extensive research- searching Medline and other online resources and read as much as I possible could about it, including the available scientific journal articles. I decided to try it.  

When I started Kratom, I had just weaned myself off of Mirapex because I was "augmenting" to the Mirapax- in other words it was making my condition worse.  Getting off of Mirapex was extremely difficult- there is even a diagnosis called "Dopamine Agonist Withdrawal Syndome."  Thankfully I was between jobs because for a few weeks I was only sleeping a couple of hours per night and my movements were drastically increased (my wife had to sleep in another bed).  When I started the Kratom I was able to sleep almost through the night.   Eventually I was able to determine that I needed just a little more at about 3am and that combined with a dose before bed allowed me to sleep through the night.  

Kratom has been a gamechanger for me- it controls my movements better than any of the pharmaceuticals.   I only use it at night and have not had issues with tolerance and haven't had to change my dose.  Online I had read that one can get addicted if it is used daily.  On more than one occasion I have stopped it cold turkey and had no symptoms of dependence.  

For me the only side effect is a little drowsiness in the morning.  As a health care professional who serves  my community and as an American, I would please urge the DEA to reconsider it stance on Kratom.   While there certainly people out there who abuse this substance-  there are also people who abuse all kinds of other substances.  I am not sure what will happen to me if I don't have access to this substance.  I should not have to suffer because of a very small number of people who abuse this.  Thank you for your consideration. 

Thank you for your consideration,

Anonymous

documents.commentText:
There are many issues I see with the scheduling of Kratom as a controlled substance. I'm nearly at a loss as to where to begin, particularly due to the lack of any veritable evidence that suggests Kratom poses imminent harm to the public. To the contrary, there appears to be veritable evidence that suggests imminent benefit to the public.

I find it troubling that a law enforcement body has been granted legislative powers with minimal oversight. The old hillbilly heart of mine would call that having the fox watch the hen house. I mean no disrespect with that analogy, but it's a precarious position and a very slippery slope. The fact of the matter is that there are countless deadly substances that the DEA is already tasked with pursuing, and asking an entity without the scientific or medical background to make determinations about the threats or benefits of a substance, in addition to the enforcement of existing laws, is a bit much. I understand the history and the governmental actions that delineated those powers, but that does not make it right or efficient. It simply means they have yet to be placed under the microscope. Perhaps, there is no need for a review of the process, but I am quite certain that an attempt to ban a seemingly harmless leaf will make a review inevitable.

I've had multiple friends die at the hands of addiction. It's not a badge of honor I wear. It's a constant reminder that I'm not always doing enough to help those whom I love the most. If there is the potential that Kratom could have saved one of those friends, then it warrants greater study. Placing it on Schedule 1 would make that study nearly impossible. 

Whenever someone, whether I care about that person that much or not, is prescribed an opiate painkiller by a practicing doctor, I plead with that person not to take it. That's how it starts all too often. We know, beyond any doubt, that prescription opiates are both addictive and deadly. I know, beyond any doubt, that Kratom is not deadly and no more addictive than coffee. If it has the potential to be an alternative to a pharmaceutical narcotic with deadly qualities, does it not merit a chance? 

I don't know when things reached the point where we currently reside. I'm talking about the point where I am told what natural substances I can and cannot put in my body. I understand the attempt to protect the public from manufactured narcotics. I don't always agree with the methodology, but I understand the intent. I will never understand the intent behind denying an individual the personal freedom of choosing to ingest a leaf, or bean or stick (if that's a person's thing). Forgive me for being crass for a moment, but it's not illegal for me to wipe my butt with poison ivy. That act would cause considerable damage, create medical cost and certainly impact my ability to work for a few days. Should we place poison ivy on Schedule 1?

I live in Florida, and the Congress of Florida recently shot down a bill that would have banned Kratom. The lone argument the proponents of the bill had was that Kratom could POTENTIALLY make a heroin user relapse and start using heroin again. If that's logic, then I should have failed my logic class in college. If a person wants to use heroin, that decision will be made regardless of if he/she ingests Kratom, potatoes, dried rosemary or anything else. Should we stop giving diabetics insulin because it may encourage them to start consuming sugar again? That statement is sadly more logical. 

I use Kratom for anxiety. I am not addicted, and I do not use it every day. I do not consume alcohol or any other "drugs." I have a prescription for a fairly potent anxiety medication, because my anxiety is rather severe. But, that medication carries with it grave harmful possibilities. I would much prefer to take something natural when the need arises. Something that has been in use for centuries with zero documented direct causal deaths. 

There is information available, but it is apparent that it was never consulted. Please respect our freedoms, and please trust that the American people do know what is best for them at the end of the day.

I am a mid-30s, female, state government employee. I have never used Kratom, nor any Scheduled Substance (except in cases of surgery or severe injury). Today (11/21/16) is the first day I learned of Kratom, from a comment on Amazon.com, with regards to someone asking if Kava Kava had a similar effect. I was disappointed to discover the current status of Kratom because it is a traditional medicinal plant that is being scrutinized legally condemned before being scientifically evaluated.

I have a genetic condition, known as Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (Hypermobility-Type3). As is not uncommon for those with EDS, I also have a form of autonomic nervous system dysfunction AND spontaneous spinal fluid leaks: all three conditions are known for complex and difficult to treat pain. There is a lack of standards of care for those diagnosed with either of these three conditions, and it is known that most who are affected may never be properly diagnosed. Even when we received the elusive diagnosis(es), it is difficult for medical professionals to understand and treat us, and many of us simply have to resign ourselves to being severely self-limited/disabled. Those affected, like myself, are in a medically neglected group, but our experiences are unfortunately common among those with other difficult/prolong-to-diagnosis and medically treat conditions like M.S., CFS, M.E., fibromyaligia,  lupus, etc. Disproportionately, the above medical diagnoses tend to affect women, and women are known to have their medical complaints of pain dismissed. 

I would be interested in trying Kratom to see if it provides an adjunct to OTCs, or could be used alone. I'd like to know if it will prolong my ability to work a full-time day, and/or improve my quality of life. I believe myself to be an intelligent consumer but I recognize that not everyone is. Kratom is relatively unknown in the US, its no surprise that word of its painkilling effects have an immediate interest in those who are opioid addicts affected by current regulations. Just because those who have addictions found out about Kratom earlier than those of us that would use the herbal remedy sparingly, is no reasons to declare it a Schedule 1 drug. There are many products that are abused by addicts but because they have a legitimate need and treated responsibly by the larger public, they are not banned. For example: Imodium.  

Rather than committed the resources to enforcement of a ban, it may be useful to educate people about the known risks to cut down on poison control calls. There is a lot of speculation about the side-effects of Kratom, such as psychosis, but these are reported incidents and its possible that people with mental illnesses are also addicts, which are co-using or just so happened to be using Kratom. The current situation sounds an awful lot like the history of wormwood. 

Kratom may be a valuable herbal supplement that helps reduce opioid use and dependence upon those that are without an addiction; thereby separating pain patients from high seekers; reducing the amount of legal opioid that could be illegally stolen/used and help doctors to be relieved of the complex task of pain management from those with mild-moderate chronic pain.With the DEAs blessing, I'm sure that companies will begin to invest into research and better quality control of Kratom, thereby helping to reduce any risks.

If I had to summarize: Please do not prohibited (in doing so, punish) American citizens from a reasonable herbal alternative to pain management because there exists those with complex drug addictions that will attempt any type of possible method to obtain a high. Glue, paint thinner, and cough syrup are all legal even though we know there are people that will abuse there bodies and can die from their misuse as a high. These are not Schedule substances,  Please act rationally. Thank you.

documents.commentText:
I encourage you not to implement this proposed rule.

I fail to see the need for the rule. Until you proposed banning the drug, I had never heard of the stuff. I admit that at age 69 I am not at the forefront of youth culture, but it does seem to me that if the drug was causing a significant problem it would at least be in the news occasionally. I would prefer not to have my tax dollars spent on a solution in search of a problem.

I see little evidence that prohibition would accomplish anything useful.  Edward M. Brecher and the staff of Consumer's Union summed it up  in the 1972 book "Licit and Illicit Drugs." They said. "Prohibition doesn't work. It should work, but it doesn't."  I don't believe there is any indication that prohibition actually keeps people from using drugs. It certainly didn't keep anybody who wanted a drink from getting one in the 1920s. Al Capone and the other bootleggers were happy to help out. 

All prohibition does is change the supplier, from somebody legal that you can keep an eye on, to an illegal drug dealer over whom you have no control. It also breeds contempt for the law, corruption, and violence. In sum, I believe the negative effects of a prohibition on society far outweigh any slight benefit it might have.

Drug use can indeed be a problem, but it is a medical and social problem, not a law enforcement problem. Our law enforcement personnel are generally excellent, but it is unfair to ask them to be medical doctors and social workers. They aren't trained for it and the unique tool they have to work with (the ability to arrest people) is no way to deal with a person who has a drug problem. 

Besides doing little or nothing to actually help a person with a drug problem, arresting them costs money! Trials cost money. Putting them in prison costs even more money.  Why spend all that money on enforcing a prohibition that doesn't work when decent drug treatment and counseling -- things that actually work -- cost a fraction as much?

I hope you drop your plans for this proposed rule.

Docket No. DEA-442W
 Schedules of Controlled Substances: Temporary Placement of Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine into Schedule I; Withdrawal.

     Given the widespread moral, political and scientific consensus that drug use and addiction are best treated as health issues, there's no good reason for people who use kratom to be treated as criminals - especially considering how much we already know about prohibition's shamefully disproportionate impact on people of color and other marginalized groups.
- Reasons kratom should NOT be banned include (but aren't limited to):  
    1.) Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
    2.) If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars before ANY potential medicinal/theraputic research can occur.
    3.) Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever, mood regulator, and even an opioid replacement in some cases.
    4.) Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
    5.) Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
    6.) Kratom can be effective in combating the symptoms of opioid withdrawal and the dangers of opioid use (especially dangerous/deadly "street opioids"), but does not function as an opioid "mimicker".    

     We should strive to make informed decisions regarding public policy - especially when health and safety are concerned. We need not continue down the path of premature, ignorance-fed, fear-induced, & irrational criminalization of a plant (or it's active ingredient) that shows such potential for positive social, personal, and/or medicinal/therapeutic impact. 

Thank you.

documents.commentText:
Five years ago, after undergoing arm surgery, I was prescribed opioids for "pain management. I was new to the world of prescription pain medication, and at the time, did not realize the addictive properties of the pills I was being prescribed. 

Over the course of the next two years, there was no attempt by the doctor to taper my dosage or lessen the number of pills that I was prescribed each month. I eventually took it upon myself to request that my prescribed opioid amount be lowered every month. The withdrawals were painful, but after 4 months of self-prescribed "tapering", I was off the medication completely. 

After several weeks, the pain returned, yet I still maintained a commitment to be drug free and chose to deal with the pain rather than be dependent on any medication.

A few months later I heard about a plant called "Kratom", and its effects regarding pain management. My friend had been using it as a treatment for his anxiety disorder, and recommended that I try it to alleviate my pain. 

I have never really been put much faith in herbal or natural remedies, as I could never really tell if they were working according to their claims, but after taking my first dosage (1 teaspoon), I found that my pain, while not fully dissipated, had substantially subsided. I maintained a regimen of two teaspoons per day for five months. 

Eventually, I stopped taking kratom as well due to a desire to be unfettered from the burden of taking supplements. Unlike the opioids, when I stopped taking Kratom...there were no withdrawal symptoms. There was not a single physical or mental reaction to the cessation of ingesting this plant.

Unfortunately, due to the DEA's possible ban on Kratom which would classify it as a Schedule 1 drug, millions of Americans may not have the freedom to oversee their pain management as they see fit. The DEA's claim that Kratom is "an imminent hazard to the public safety", is nonsense.

Public opinion leans towards the belief that this action by the DEA is merely an attempt to suppress a business that is in competition with the interests of the pharmaceutical companies under the guise of "protecting the public". The DEA seems to be operating merely as guardians of the big-pharma monopoly.  

The agency also claims there have been "numerous deaths associated with kratom,". Such a case does not appear to exist, and most users report that consuming too much kratom will only lead to nausea and vomiting.

Of the 30 total documented deaths associated with kratom around the world, many tests found that subjects had been abusing other drugs or suffering from other pre-existing health conditions. To put that into context, around 25,000 people died from prescription overdoses in the United States in 2014.

It is preposterous that at a time when this country is seeing the largest opiate epidemic crisis in our history, the DEA is poised to put an inexpensive, all natural alternative in the same category as Heroin and LSD, effectively banning it from all consumption or research.

The drug war has proven to be a failed policy, yet the government still adheres to the notion that eradication of drugs and addiction is a realistic possibility.

The CDC reported that poison control centers received over 660 calls between 2010 and 2015 regarding kratom intoxication. These numbers pale in comparison to the death from prescription opioid abuse.

Overdose deaths involving prescription opioids have quadrupled since 1999. From 1999 to 2014, more than 165,000 people have died in the U.S. from overdoses related to prescription opioids. In 2014, more than 14,000 people died from overdoses involving prescription opioids.

I feel that the DEA is banning a substance that has potential clinical utility for recovering addicts and people living with pain. Something that has a proven record of accomplishment should be regulated and not banned.

During a time when attitudes towards naturally occurring products are becoming more and more acceptable, as in the case of marijuana, it seems that the DEA's threat is a major step backwards. It is an affront to the premise that people are smart enough to make their own choices and decisions for themselves regarding their health.

There is no doubt in my mind that without access to Kratom, thousands of people suffering from pain, anxiety disorders and alcohol withdrawals will be forced to seek out these pain pills once more, ultimately creating a black market for these substances. Drug usage alone should not be a moral issue- it is merely a choice some people make, but by making Kratom illegal, the DEA will in fact be creating crime where none had previously existed.

People have every right to make their own health decisions as they see fit, and I believe that any naturally occurring herb, plant or leaf, should be a person's right to consume if he or she chooses to do so. 

Thank you for your time.

I'm a 48 year old woman, mechanical engineer and spouse of an Air Force retiree.  I'm writing about my belief that Kratom does not belong on the Schedule 1 controlled substance list, and that banning the plant would cause harm and suffering to me and to millions of people. I've lived a pretty straight-laced life and would not be commenting here if my personal research and experience had led me to believe that Kratom is addictive like opioids or illegal drugs, is dangerous to people using it, or is similar to a street drug used recreationally and and with a high incidence of death. I take Kratom to improve my life by helping me deal with physical pain, depression and the lack of motivation caused by these problems. I dont want to get high, and Kratom does not cause that effect.  Actually taking too high a dose makes people nauseous and vomit. Opioids pain medicine prescribed by my doctors made me feel nauseous, dizzy and gave me migraines after taking it. Learning about the potential for abuse of and addiction to opioids led me to look for alternatives. Many people have turned away from opioids and street drugs to Kratom to help feel healthier, and banning it would force people to turn back to dangerous legal medications and illicit drugs. 

Many people have already cited scientific sources and referenced letters of support for Kratom remaining legal from Congress, doctors, therapists, other professional people and military vets with PTSD and pain. I wanted to add my story and support for keeping Kratom legal. It is a plant, a natural supplement. I don't believe it is safer nor more dangerous than taking other OTC herbal supplements, vitamins or unregulated food supplements that people use every day.  None or them are regulated or overseen by FDA. I understand that additional scientific research would be beneficial and methods to ensure its purity and safety would be welcome, but to classify it as a Schedule 1 controlled substance like heroin, LSD or HDMA would be injurious to many Americans and a big mistake. 

I started using Kratom only this year after feeling like my life was being ruined by chronic pain and depression. I have limited mobility from back and knee pain that has kept me from doing activities that normal people do, like working, shopping, walking the dog, doing house chores. The conventional medical system has helped me somewhat, but I needed to find more reliable alternatives that could actually help me meet some goals in life. Kratom is the most effective means I've found to safely help me feel physically better and feel motivated to do positive activities in my life. I have worked with pain doctors in the military health system and civilian sector, have had procedures and operations on my back and knees, done extensive physical therapy, and used Percocet to lower pain. I receive treatment for depression with psychiatrist prescribed medicines and by seeing a mental health counselor. Doctors have provided me with the best treatments that they can. The treatments have not provided the relief Ive needed, but Kratom has allowed me to live a decent life. If I lose the legal right to use Kratom, a safe natural supplement, my life will change for the worse.

documents.commentText: I would like to mention, when I ask someone if they have ever heard of Kratom, 75% of people I ask, maybe more, reply "What's Kratom?". With that said I would have to say, calling it an epidemic, or saying it's like "legal heroin", is very inaccurate, and uneducated. Even at high doses, it does not provide a very pleasurable experience. I remember years ago when I first discovered the plant, I over did it a few times, and got very nauseous. Not very enjoyable. I feel the overdosing on Kratom alone, and I stress alone, would be near impossible. I'm no scientist, but just the fact that you have to consume so much plant matter speaks for itself. The body isn't used to that much fiber. High fiber foods are 2-3 grams per serving. If we're talking about high doses of Kratom, 12-18 grams just wouldn't seem appealing to most. We know people have a problem with moderation. I'll just mention, take a look at the statistic of alcoholism, or alcohol consumption, in America. It's horrifying. I heard on the radio, that Heroin related deaths, have now out numbered, traffic related(alcohol related or not) deaths, and homicide. Now that is something we call an epidemic. Now, this is a Wisconsin statistic, one of the 5 states that banned Kratom. Is this a coincidence? Kratom has been proven to be a huge help in the recovery of heroin addicts. How can we overlook something that is helping the remedy of our current Heroin problem. There is always going to be a handful of those who give something a bad name, by acting irresponsibly. Lets not take all the great benefits it offer to most, because of people acting irresponsibly. Again, I will mention alcohol. This is a known poison. This is a known killer. We can slap a disclaimer on it that says, "Drink Responsibly" and all is well. I saying right now, all is not well. I've lost too much from alcohol. A disclaimer won't bring back my best friend. He wasn't responsible enough, or able to practice enough self-control. His death will forever effect my life, and his other friends, and family. This is just one incident. Lets think about everyone who has passed, from alcohol related incidences. Some not even the one acting irresponsibly. The precious disclaimer did nothing to save all those lives. Yet I walk past numerous places that are legally selling it, and giving people a venue to consume it. I think potential misuse of the Kratom plant, should be far from the top of our list of priorities. I agree that we as a nation, should do more research on the plant. Professional research on it's benefits, as well as any potential hazards. I think this will take a long time. So let's focus on more pressing issues, like the ones I've mentioned above. I think taking away someone's morning tea, which helps them get through a day of chronic pain, is counteractive. I know it takes money out of "Big Pharmacy's" pocket. Which is less revenue that the government can tax. I sure hope that's not a factor. Taking away the tea, and replacing it with oxycodone, or hydrocodone, is no answer. That is just asking for more addiction, more overdoses, more recovery. In wrapping up, I must say that the BEA's approach to market Kratom more responsibly, through honesty, is a great and appropriate movement. Its a huge industry. A taxable industry. So all vendors selling it as "incense" or for "research only", can just sell it for what it is to most...medicine.

I dont drink alcohol, I dont use drugs, I dont smoke cigarettes. I vote in every election, I pay my taxes, I go to church on Sundays & volunteer in the church nursery and at my kids' school. But until last year I had been on opiate painkillers for 13 years. I was in a car accident that left me with permanent disc damage in my cervical spine and I was in constant pain. I was told I could take the pills or have surgery, but that they didnt recommend surgery because it has a high risk of paralysis and isnt always effective.

So I took the pills. They did help with the pain. They also slowed my capacities, made me lethargic, foggy, withdrawn and ill-tempered. I took them as little as possible but they were right. My pain did get worse as time went on. I went through two pregnancies, had two little babies who needed to be held and rocked and carried, two little children who I needed to bend over and kneel down and crawl around with. Things got much worse. I was able to maintain my daily dosage of Percocet, but I couldnt go without it. Worse, even if I did have a low pain day, I couldnt just skip a pill anymore. Do you know what your brain does when you have been giving it opiates and then stop? It sends even louder pain messages to your body trying to get you to take the Percocet. So even on a day when Id be in less pain than normal, I had to take the pills on time just to prevent the pain from ramping up and becoming unbearable. 

Then I tried kratom. I was scared at first, I thought it was either some hippy dippy, useless natural remedy that would do nothing or that it was really this street drug that was going to make me high. As Ive said, I am an extremely sober, conservative person, and my children mean the whole world to me. I would never take something that would seriously hinder my ability to take care of them properly. Finally, I had read enough about it that I felt it was worth a shot. I waited until my kids had gone to bed, just in case it did make me weird or loopy, so itd have worn off before they woke up.

Do you know what happened? 45 minutes later, I felt NORMAL. I didnt feel high or euphoric or drugged or confused or jittery or anything chemical at all. I felt like a normal, pain free human being. It was literally like being let out of prison after 13 years. Kratom gave me back to my family. It allowed me to run and laugh and play with my children again, instead of being tired or short tempered because I felt bad from the pain or the painkillers. It gave me my life back and I couldnt believe how easy it was to stop taking Percocet almost overnight.

I oppose the DEAs Intent to Schedule the alkaloids Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine, which would make Kratom (Mitragynaspeciosa), the most severe classification of schedule I.  I have consumed kratom a handful of times myself. I found out about kratom from a tea shop that served kratom as a relaxation aide, along with kava root, chamomile, and other common herbs and spices that are rather well known and DEA/FDA approved for food. Kava and chamomile are both touted by retailers as relaxation aides as well. I have a clinical anxiety disorder and find kava root to be helpful. With my limited experience of kratom, it seemed to be helpful in the same regard. Not once did I feel a compulsion to continue significant use. I clearly have the genetic disposition for addiction, but have no desire, intent, or compulsion to consume kratom any more than I do coffee, green tea, or kava. It's obviously not an availability issue, as a simple Internet search to buy it from numerous vendors is a mouse click away.

This notion is echoed by existing scientific literature. Studies have shown kratom has a low risk of dependency or addiction. Furthermore, their observations clearly show potential for use as an aide in opioid addiction treatment. Given that opioid abuse is seeing a resurgence in recent years, and has been an ever-present problem for humanity, there's a dire need for further inquiry into the potential for kratom's clinical use. I have had conversations with multiple people that have suffered an opioid addiction, tried kratom, and found it a useful tool in their recovery. They're not stealing from their families to find their next high anymore, and are ostensibly living healthy and successful lives now as hard-working, tax-paying fellow citizens. I personally have nothing to add to this particular objection, as I have never abused opiates, but their stories of being able to kick a well-known, painfully strong addiction with help from a simple non-addictive herb, is astounding.

Despite all this, I am not necessarily an advocate of the substance for any particular purpose. My main objection, as stated above, is that we're considering as a nation to place a felony ban on a substance that apparently

a.) has a LOW potential for abuse.
b.) HAS currently (albeit preliminarily) accepted medical use in treatment in the United States.
c.) There is an ABUNDANCE of accepted safety for use.

Kratom has records of use since at least the 19th century, yet to date not a single person has died as a direct result of kratom consumption. Studies have shown it doesn't cause respiratory depression, the leading cause of death in opiate overdoses. The kratom plant nor it's constituents are not classified as an opiate, as they are not a part of the opium family of plants. Rather, kratom is a member of the coffee family. Let's also keep in mind that hundreds of thousands of people die every year of heart disease, often precipitated by the federally-approved yet medically-confirmed lethally high diet of fats, sugars, and tobacco.

It is estimated that fatal doses of caffeine for humans are between 3 and 20 grams taken orally, depending on body weight and tolerance. An average cup of coffee contains 1/15 or less than an estimated lethal dose. Yet America drinks this substance daily, with no fear of this threat. If the concern is for public health, we're looking in the wrong place. The DEA's current proposal is to criminalize kratom with the same severity as heroin. This comparison is patently false given the current literature. Despite this, and sound evidence for a potentially highly effective method of drug abuse recovery, the DEA is proposing that we regulate and add more legal mechanisms to waste our tax payer dollars, and our nation's finest law enforcement's time, trying to enforce this to keep our society safe from a substance that's very likely as safe for human consumption as the traditional coffee plant.

IF the DEA must schedule kratom, let's be reasonable and place it in schedule V so that clinical testing for potential as an addiction remedy may continue. However, it's not currently shown to have dependency or abuse risks, so my opinion is to leave this concern for the FDA to review its existing approval as a food additive or dietary supplement. Further research is necessary, but please do not lock kratom into a scheduled status where history proves it will never return from. I'd rather not see my tax dollars wasted worrying about a non-toxic species of coffee. I think there are far more pressing issues both of these agencies need to attend to, such as protecting us from the very real, very dangerous and predatory drug cartels, both black market and corporate. Thank you for your time.

In my opinion, the DEA should not classify the active components of kratom as Schedule 1 drugs.

I first tried this towards the end of 2013, and stopped around a year later. I was in college, and money was tight, so I cut spending where I could. 

One idea on my mind - don't ban it all, just ban the extracts and concentrated forms. Limit the amount of kratom's active components in products, like caffeine?

I just think you can do a better job than a blanket ban on a potentially useful substance for many, as this would disrupt many lives of good people.

documents.commentText: I am writing to strongly urge you not to move forward with the DEA recommendation for temporary placement of mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine into Schedule 1.  My understanding is that the original concern emanated from the CDC after a review of data suggesting that kratom had been involved in a small number of poison control reports, small relative to the large number of poison control reports received each year in the U.S.  Inexplicably, those reports led to a recommendation to place  mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine into Schedule 1, a schedule reserved for substances with no potential for medical benefit and great potential for abuse.  There is a complete absence of data to suggest that kratom has a great potential for abuse and a huge volume of experience from people who have used kratom for management of chronic pain to suggest that with research, there is indeed great potential for medical benefit.  Placing kratom into Schedule 1 would immediately stop any possibility of research into its potential for medical benefit.  At a time when the entire country is suffering from the effects of opiate addiction and overdose, much of it linked to misuse of prescription medications for pain, it seems foolhardy in the extreme to close the door on substances that might have the potential to offer relief for chronic pain without the downsides of addiction, withdrawal, and overdose seen with prescription and non-prescription opioids.  Rather than slamming the door on its potential benefits for millions of people suffering from chronic pain in the U.S., a more fruitful strategy would be to regulate and fund and promote research.

My name is Andrew Perkey.  I am 29 years old, and I work as a restaurant manager in Burlington, North Carolina.  I also work part-time and seasonally as a musician, and as a graphic design assistant in the textile industry.  I am writing to describe my experience with Mitragyna speciosa, also known as kratom, as a dietary supplement.  My intent is to explain my opposition to the proposed placement of it's component alkaloids, mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine, on the list of Schedule 1 controlled substances.

To begin, I feel I must share the fact that I have suffered from a variety of health problems throughout my life, which have crippled my ability to function in many ways. documents.commentText:
The following comment is in regard to Docket No. DEA-442W. I am a 28 year old male and I first discovered kratom seven years ago when looking into natural dietary supplements that were said to help assist in managing symptoms related to anxiety and depression. For well over a decade I have been diagnosed by several professionals with these issues, as well as Obsessive Compulsive Disorder, and have sought just about every avenue available in dealing with these conditions. Allow me to preface this by saying I am not at all claiming that kratom is a medicine or some kind of cure-all remedy. I recognize there is no magic bullet and that it is not something I should permanently rely on. That being said, since Ive begun taking this supplement as needed (in safe, moderate amounts, and not on a daily basis), in addition to regular exercise and meditation, I have been successful in managing many of the symptoms of my anxiety and depression. Additionally, because my anxiety levels are much lower, the symptoms of my Obsessive Compulsive Disorder are much less pronounced, making my day to day life much more tolerable.
Years ago there were instances where I literally could not leave my house because of the levels of anxiety I was experiencing. I would often get terrible panic attacks where I thought I was about to die, so much so that I had to stop working for a while. My grades in school started to fall because I found myself unable to go to class some days. There were days my Obsessive Compulsive Disorder was so bad I didnt want to leave my bed, in irrational fears of getting poisoned or sick by the germs I perceived to be coating every surface and floor outside of my meticulously sanitized room. If it wasnt the anxiety/O.C.D., it was the depression, days not eating or getting off the couch because I was so consumed by mental agony and suicidal thoughts that I did not want to move. I could not focus on anything, was constantly either gaining or losing weight, and honestly didnt know how much longer I would live.
I have seen multiple therapists, doctors, and psychologists for the state of my mental health. For years I was on numerous antidepressants (trying about eight or nine different kinds), several anti-anxiety medications for daily use and--for when my panic attacks were especially bad--benzodiazepines. At first these medications would help a little bit, but then after a while my problems would come back. Sometimes, my symptoms came back even worse. So again and again I would be switched over to new medications, many of which basically turned me into a zombie. There were pills I was prescribed that made me sleep for sixteen hours a day, and when I was finally awake, I was in a mental fog and couldnt think straight, often to the point of feeling impaired. It was nearly impossible to function in my day to day life. Other prescribed medications gave me suicidal thoughts, and on more than one occasion, very disturbing paranoia. I began contemplating applying for Disabilities from the government because I wasnt sure I was able to work again, even though I was a young person who wanted to get a decent job, work hard, and be a productive member of society. 
My life turned around after discovering kratom. Through a combination of therapy, exercise, anxiety-reducing thought techniques, meditation, and using various dietary supplements and herbs, of which kratom is the most helpful, I was able to drastically improve in managing the symptoms of these problems Ive had. To reiterate, just because kratom and my lifestyle changes allowed me to get off my prescribed medications, it does not mean I am claiming kratom as a medicinal replacement to these drugs, just that it allowed me to get my symptoms under control and move forward in improving my general well-being. Since then my life has improved in many ways: I've maintained a serious romantic relationship, received a bachelor's degree, had several job promotions, drink less, and live an overall healthier and happier life. 
Do some people overdo kratom? Sure. Does that mean we have to punish the vast majority of kratom consumers simply because a handful of people took more than what is recommended and had a bad experience? Should we outlaw people enjoying a glass of wine because a segment of the population abuses alcohol?
I would like to see kratom sold only to adults, labeled with similar guidelines as other supplements such as kava kava, and only sold in a pure, unadulterated form. The city of Denver recently implemented similar policies, which are completely rational. Kratom is not dangerous. I have used it for years now and I am in excellent physical health and have had no problems with it. I don't know where I would be without it.
I appreciate the willingness of the DEA to open up this public comment period. Please keep this supplement legal and available, so many people have found that it has improved their lives. Thank you for your time and consideration.

Banning kratom would do much more harm than good. In fact, I don't really see much good at all to come from the banning of such a useful plant. The fact that there have been no recorded deaths attributed directly to its consumption already gives kratom a better image than pharmaceutical opioids to me personally. We have an epidemic with opiates in America and the place where a lot of our addicts began was in the pharmacy with short term prescriptions of narcotic painkillers. The prescriptions run out and they turn to illicit substances like heroin because they are left physically addicted to the opioids they got from their doctor. 
 The aforementioned narcotics are killing more and more people every day. They are ruining more and more lives. They are tearing apart more and more families, they are costing our society more and more money in the population of correctional facilities, and their presence is more prominent in this country than ever before in history. 
 Again, the place that most people get hooked to narcotics to begin with is the pharmacy, with drugs considered to be "safe" and medicinally valuable. These drugs can severely slow respiratory function and can be fatal to people in even moderate doses... But a plant that people have used safely for thousands of years for many many different benefits is what we are talking about restricting access to. 
 In the past 20 years the western world has discovered that kratom can be a refuge in turning away from extremely addictive and intoxicating opioids. People find that their opiod withdrawals are much less intense when they use kratom. They are able to sleep, they are able to face their day without feeling horribly ill, and they are able to calm the mind-bending anxiety. Many people have successfully kicked their narcotic dependence with the help of kratom. It is a miracle to the people who have used it in their fight against addiction!
 The economic and environmental implications of an American ban on kratom to Indonesia specifically would be negative as well. Kratom is sustainably harvested from trees in the forest without having to cut them down or harm them. It has given people in Indonesia an opportunity at livelihood without deforestation and has recently been competing with the environmentally harmful production of palm oil - the highest contributing factor to Indonesia's rapid deforestation. Banning kratom in America would make the market much more scarce and this alternative means of making a living would be much less viable.
 All this and much more brings me to the question of who would really benefit at all from kratom being a scheduled substance? Certainly not the people suffering daily with addiction to painkillers and heroin. Those people would lose a very valuable tool in their ability to regain control of their lives. Good people who work hard for their living will be taken from their sources of income. People who don't like the intense stimulation of coffee will no longer be able to enjoy a much milder and much more pleasant alternative.
 Please reconsider your stance on the natural botanical supplement kratom. Many people will turn back to heroin and illicit use of prescriptions. That means many more people will unfortuantely die at the hands of drugs as a result. If the DEA's job is to protect us from dangerous drugs then I oblige you to leave kratom alone.

In the last year and a half since I was released from prison I started going to school for graphic design. I have been passing all my classes with A's and B's. I participate in life where before i could not function to do any of these things. 

I can't say enough how kratom has allowed me to put my life back together. I have never been able to do anything positive when taking destructive and addicting drugs. My point being is that if kratom was a destructive addicting drug, it would have been disastrous for my well being. This is absolutely not the case. Thank God for kratom.

I had minor meniscus knee surgery a few months ago and had to spend 2-3 months on hydrocodone (waiting for and then recovering from the surgery). 

I was a little worried because of everything I've read about these pills. But my friend told me about Kratom and I started using it right as the pills ran out. It definitely made the transition easy and I forgot all about the pills. 

I keep the Kratom use to a minimum though, and just use it when my knee or back pain flairs up after a longer walk or hard day. It's a mild but pleasant mood elevator, and it really does take away all my aches and pains. 

But it's also kind of gross to drink, and I like to limit it to 2-3 times a week. I'm not looking for a problem, just a pleasant pain reliever for the hard days.(and long term use of NSAIDS worry me, and don't always work, so I kind of mix it up).

I absolutely don't want Kratom banned. My comment is mostly for the purpose of saying "PLEASE DON'T BAN IT".

But I hope you do whatever you can to encourage studies and research to be done. I feel like I have a good sense for my own body, but I'd like to know what the evidence suggests. What are proper dosage amounts, and are there any long term effects? And is the product I'm buying clean and pure?  So please, regulate the process and study it. But don't ban it. 

I also want to thank your department for cancelling the decision to make it a Schedule 1 substance for 2 years. That decision gives me hope that "the government" is still listening to the (thousands of) people (who weighed in).

Hello, my name is Nate Bynum, and I would like to say as much as I can without wasting anyone's time. 
I am a combat veteran and also a disabled veteran. I know there are several others here that also have quite a bit to say on 
this matter, or would like to say something and simply can't. I'd like to speak on behalf of some of these folks, as I'm
 very much involved still with the veteran community and support fellow veterans that operate non profit organizations 
for a much greater cause than I could even put into words Over the past year, I have linked up with some of my comrades
 and have talked with many veterans of all sorts of settings. Regardless of the current professions or goals and endeavors, 
we all seem to be linked by the spirit and that is to provide selflessly to our brotherhood as well as the service to our country. 
Both items are of pretty extreme importance.

 Recently, many of us have seemed to come under attack; not by enemies of a foreign land. This time it is, what we feel, 
our personal freedom. Some of us are very broken people that had been shuffled 
through the VA and pumped fool of the same classes of pharmaceutical drugs only to yield the same result: inefficacy. 
One thing that has obviously been replacing some of these harsh narcotics are the ubiquitous and inexpensive supply 
of herbal alternatives. I used to doubt the idea of taking any substance not approved by the FDA, but I honestly believe this
 time a grave mistake has been made by not giving kratom the consideration or respect it deserves. I've used it for roughly
8 months and in absolute moderation. I can personally attest to it's usefulness, lack of side effects experienced and most
 importantly, it's ability to give back a part of my life that has been missing for some time now. 

Kratom for many of us was a source of freedom from hard medications and lack of clarity; lack of self. 
A thousand times over, it has restored many of us to what most would consider "normal". 
I do not think it is a good idea to take that right away or to criminalize something that is,
 harmless without honoring it for what it has done for many of these wonderful people. The feeling is a consensus among us 
and we do see the DEA's stance on kratom as a threat to our livelihood. I don't want to go on about the benefits because that
 is simply not my place, but I would like to speak on the very principle of what is happening here. We have elected to choose 
to put something in our bodies that has come with no proven ill-effects. I've looked at the information regarding kratom on 
many of these .gov sites, and it's insufficient. I think as the greatest government in the world, we could certainly do better on 
being more scrupulous with our case studies. I encourage that the DEA take a few steps back and not see kratom as another 
drug out there in the wild that needs to be taken on because the number of users and types of users vary so widely that it is as
 if you are looking at all of the faces that make up America in itself. I do not think your everyday American is a crook or a 
delinquent. I urge you not to start a war against a substance that is doing so much good for the men and women that have
 sworn on their lives to uphold the highest code of integrity and give good for you.

 If you or anyone reading this is a veteran, 
I thank you for your service, and I thank you for sharing the burdens with me. I have a sincere passion for doing what is right, 
what is fair and what is honestly for the better. Thank you for all that you do as an organization. I, too, appreciate the safety 
you try to bring to our culture and way of life. I just do not believe that kratom is here to cause anyone any harm or provide 
the financing to criminal activities. I've looked into it practically and economically, and I think we will do just fine with the 
regards we had for it prior to August 31st of this year. Again, I'm very grateful for this opportunity to say my piece and I sure
 hope this address is not falling into a void among the rest of them. Godspeed, my friends.

A lot of people have successfully used kratom as a tool to suppress drug cravings and find stability in their life. I truly believe if kratom is made illegal it will lead more opiod overdoses, and is losing even one person worth it?

If this goes into effect, thousands of law-abiding citizens across  will become potential felons. Approximately three years ago, I was prescribed anti-depressants after being diagnosed with depression. My psychiatrist, at that time, prescribed me with a few different SSRI's and a dopamergenic. I know that for some people, anti-depressants may work, however they had an adverse affect on me and the side effects far outweighed the benefits. I found that the SSRI's made my depression worse. I tapered off the medication, which was difficult, even though I was only on them for a couple of months. At that time, I heard about Kratom and decided to give it a try. I consumed Kratom for approximately two months in the wake of my negative experience with prescription medications. Kratom did not cure or treat my depression, however it noticeably enhanced my quality of life. I still struggled with depression and I still had anxiety, however, Kratom helped promote a sense of well being that made it possible to get through those two months and still be a productive member of society. To further expound upon how Kratom has helped me, yet not treated any condition of mine, I would like to go into detail about just what my condition is. Recently, I discovered through a gene test that I have a genetic mutation of the MTHFR gene and this means that my body does convert folic acid into methylfolate which is the precursor to serotonin, dopamine and norepinephrine. I have been supplementing with a prescribed medical food, L-methylfolate, which has targeted that genetic anomaly and balanced it, therefore increasing my serotonin, dopamine and norepinephrine levels safely and naturally without any adverse affects. Also, my serotonin transporter has a genetic mutation where the presynaptic transmembrane protein (SLC6A4) has an intermediate risk of being non-response. Essentially my serotonin levels can pool up, therefore generating large risk with any intake of a prescribed SSRI. This also means that my glutamate levels are higher than the average person, which can generate large amounts of anxiety and also create insomnia because your brain cannot turn off. I would like to reiterate and say that Kratom did not fix these gene mutations and increase my serotonin levels like L-methylfolate has, nor did it force my glutamate levels down like a prescribed medication would. However, in that transitory phase of my life, Kratom safely helped promote a healthy lifestyle and gave me the energy to continue working. It's a safe alternative to caffeine and I would like to compare and explain why Kratom is safer than caffeine. I consumed a lot of caffeine in my years prior to my experience with Kratom, and it damaged my health. Caffeine acts on the adrenal glands, which is the bodies primary defense against stress. With my genetic variations, stress and depression were amplified, and when my adrenal glands were exhausted, I had no physiological defense against that stress which contributed to developing GERD and other digestive imbalances. Kratom has proven to me to be safer than caffeine and has not had any negative impact on my body like caffeine has nor has it inhibited my bodies ability to fight stress. Granted, when it comes to fighting bacterial and viral infections, there is no replacement for proper diet and sleep. I implore the FDA to do rigorous testing of Kratom and allow for data to be put fourth from many reputable and independent sources in order to prevent bias.

Firstly, I would like to ask the DEA as to why they chose to pursue a ruling over Kratom before the synthetic substance, U-47700. I am aware that they have stated their ruling to schedule Kratom was in the interest of public safety, and I believe public safety should be top priority. However, as reported by FoxNews in June of 2016, research chemical U-47700 was directly responsible for fifty plus deaths nationwide in a span of less than a year. This poses a much greater danger to public safety than any recorded threat of Kratom, however legal action was first initiated against the natural plant Kratom and not synthetic chemical U-47700. This leads me to my next question, will the DEA publicly release the footnotes that were the basis for their decision to schedule Kratom under the FOIA?
 In conclusion, Kratom has been legal for over two decades in the US and has never caught on as a recreational high. It does not incapacitate the brain like alcohol does and has a long history of safe use. Please keep Kratom legal.

My name is Joseph Bishko, I am 39 years old, and from Asheville NC. I am a Social Worker and help support people with Intellectual and Developmental Disabilities  and their families obtain necessary State funded and Medicaid funded services that they need to live the best quality of life possible and to support inclusion into their community. I am a strong advocate for the I/DD community and have been since 1998.  I now find myself advocating for myself as well as other responsible people throughtout America who take an herbal supplement to ensure they have a good quality of life. These are other responsible people like me, who may have anxiety, pain, depression, PTSD, that have decided to utilize a more organic and natural way of life instead of taking pharmaceutical drugs. I would like to 
voice my concern about The DEA's decision to ban and put Kratom on Schedule 1 substance list without an educated understanding of what Kratom is. To ban Kratom and label it closely related to an opiate is dangerous. Kratom is related to coffee, is a plant, is natural and not man made in some big pharma lab, and has been used for thousands of years. By banning Kratom,  a regulated dietary ingredient, will stop important scientific research. A ban will also decrease the quality of life for so many people. 
I began using Kratom to manage my back pain in 2013.  I learned about Kratom from a friend who studied Pharmacology and decided to turn her attention to Herbal Pharmacology after identifying better results from using natural and homeopathic remedies not synthetic drugs made in laboratories.  She has increased the quality of life for so many people with diagnoses that include diabetes, MS, PTSD and chronic pain. I am one of them.
I was always active as a dancer, in gymnastics and some sports. I had an injury in college, late 90s, to my lower back. I have gone through physical therapy, regular chiropractic appointments along with massage and it has been determined I will eventually need back surgery. I have been prescribed multiple painkillers since the late 90s that have included oxycodone and hydrocodone. The side effects of these drugs, and at times reliance, caused many side effects that have included depression. With depression came another plethora of drugs.  I was prescribed antidepressants including Zoloft, Paxil, Wellbutrin and Prozac. With antidepressants came so many side effects and the only one that had the least was Prozac. However, in 2004 I attempted suicide as a side effect from Prozac.  With the increase in prescription opioid abuse and side effects I searched for another alternative and turned to my friend for support, assistance and natural plan of care.  I use a variety of natural products and herbal supplements that include turmeric, willow bark, essential oils, cod oil and Kratom.  I no longer take any prescription painkillers, antidepressants or even over the counter medications; Tylenol. I am now more active, work out 4 to 5 times a week and feel surgery is far down the road!   My quality of life has increased by the use of Kratom.  As of October 1st I was very concerned I would be a felon, along with many other responsible people, without providing any input on how Kratom has provided me a better quality of life without the use of opioids or other medications.
To attempt to label Kratom as a controlled substance, schedule 1, an opiod or synthetic is  not responsible. I do no buy my Kratom at a head shop or a gas station but from a safe and reliable herbal supplement vendor. Kratom is a safe and natural alternative to all opiod medications and not in any way as dangerous as what is listed for scheduled 1 controlled substance. People overdose on heroin and legal substances including alcohol and prescription painkillers.  With the opioid epidemic currently happening all around this country it is harmful to take away a plant that people are choosing to use instead of opioids.  This ban will be turning  people who drink tea into criminals. The DEA's attention  and Federal money would be better spent on more facilities and more/better access to Mental Health and Substance Use treatment.  The number of people needing substance use and mental health treatment will only increase and I hope the funds will be there to support all of us as this will fall on the state of NC to provide.  I have worked in the MH/SU and I/DD field for close to 15 years now and see the small amount of of money and support currently being provided so I also can see this from a different angle. Please, reconsider an outright ban of a natural plant that continues to help so many people to live a great quality of life free of potentially dangerous prescription drugs.  As a responsible person in a noble profession I'll continue to choose a more natural way to live the best quality of life. 

Sincerely, 
Joseph Bishko

To Whom It May Concern:
I have spent my career teaching, counseling, and advocating for at-risk youth. I am well-acquainted with the dangers of illegal drug use. I have never used an opioid illegally and have no dependence- my only narcotic use has been post-surgery.

In 2014, I picked up mono. About 9 months later, I was diagnosed with Chronic Myalgic Encephalitis. This condition has severely altered the course of my life. I was unable to work full-time for over two years. My physical health suffered tremendously, and I now deal with anxiety and emotional issues that I could not have imaged before.

I have worked with upwards of a dozen healthcare providers- I have seen anti-immune, infectious disease, and psychiatric specialists. The pharmaceutical industry doesn't offer a cure or effective treatment. The drugs that do offer minor relief have significant side-effects and come at great financial cost. 

I have made significant lifestyle changes: I have recently moved out to Utah and taken a lower-stress job in the hopes that I may begin rebuilding a life for myself. But nothing has been more effective in helping me to work and maintain relationships with family and a handful of friends than Kratom. 

I don't take Kratom every day- in fact, I try and take it as infrequently as possible. But I can't hold a job if I'm constantly too worn out to work. I won't be able to maintain relationships or my emotional health if I am constantly worried that spending time with others will jeopardize my ability to hold a job.

I have never experience any significant side effects from the use of Kratom. I get my blood and liver tested regularly and have seen no sign for concern.

I would not be opposed to greater regulation of this supplement, and I certainly support greater study. I have no wish to see anyone harmed by misuse of what is clearly an effective substance. While I am not prone to conspiracy theories, the fashion in which the kratom ban was proposed by the DEA sparks of pharmaceutical industry intervention. We allow alcohol and nicotine in grocery stores, and a number of states now allow for recreational consumption of marijuana, but the DEA has proposed forbidding the single substance that has ever effectively helped me mitigate my illness.

I implore the DEA to reconsider this ban, allow for study of Kratom's usefulness and potential harm, and I encourage the FDA to regulate the supplement to help ensure its purity and safety.

There are few options for those of us in pain beyond NSAIDS.  Kratom is an herbal supplement with a unique profile (at least in my observations):pain relief without sedation or loss of clarity.  

We have seen no indication of habituation.  Stopping use after a period of daily use causes no discomfort.  I find no "urge" to use Kratom, no desire to increase dose.  In fact, higher doses are unpleasant, inducing nausea.

The safety profile (from my observations) is far superior to dangerous narcotics.  There is no addiction or craving,  accidental "overdoses" are impossible and there is no recreational use.

RE: Docket No. DEA-442W

On January 21, 2011, I, Sara Chmiel, did heroin for the last time. I was 26 years old. 
On June 1, 2013, Kyle Mason, my friend of 14 years, overdosed on heroin and died. He was 30 years old.
On November 17, 2016, Lisa Smith, my aunt, overdosed on heroin and died. She was 46 years old.
I wrote those dates here to show that I have had personal experience with drug abuse and its consequences, and that the opiate epidemic in our country has affected my life in irreparable ways. 


I've suffered from severe depression my entire life, and had multiple suicide attempts, beginning at the age of 10 and the last at the age of 27. Then last year, I was diagnosed with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome type III, Raynaud's phenomenon, early-onset osteoarthritis, and degenerative disc disease. Now, at 32 years old, I suffer from pinched nerves in both my neck and lower back, muscle spasms, fatigue, and anxiety as a result of my chronic, incurable illness. I've been told that I would have a better prognosis if I had Lupus, as the only course of action for my doctors is to treat my symptoms as they emerge.

Before kratom, I felt hopeless. I missed work, and couldn't sleep for more than an hour at a time, because of my pain level. I wasn't showering, wasn't eating, and wasn't maintaining interpersonal relationships. I was terrified of losing my job, of being physically unable to continue to work, and of what my future would be, living in constant pain. I was terrified of not being able to take care of myself. I was more depressed and suicidal than I've ever been before, and that scared me more than anything else. I was being prescribed pain killers, but as someone with a history of opiate drug abuse, I knew that I would either begin to use more and more of the pain killers, or go through terrible withdrawal symptoms in order to stop. I just wanted to be able to do normal everyday activities, keep a job, have friends, take care of myself - all the things my chronic pain and illness had taken away from me - without being dependent on a doctor or a pill just to function like any other person. The worst part was how often I found myself thinking about doing heroin again, and how much easier it would have been for me to get heroin off the street than it was to get anything to help from my doctor.

Then I found kratom, and it helped me stop using the prescription pain pills and get my life back.

I started using kratom 3 months ago. I'm still under a doctor's care, and have radio-frequency ablation done on my neck every few months, but kratom has been the only thing I take for my muscle spasms and pain. I've found that it also alleviates my anxiety and fatigue, and has helped me do the simplest things like clean my apartment, go to the grocery store, or take a shower. I haven't missed a single day of work since I started taking kratom, and I'm working on strengthening relationships with the loved ones in my life. It doesn't affect my thinking or my moods the way prescription pain pills did, and I haven't experienced any type of withdrawal symptoms when I've stopped its use. It's not a cure-all, and I still experience some pain on a daily basis, but kratom makes enough of a difference that I haven't felt any desire for anything more potent. With kratom in my life, I feel more capable than I have in a very long time. I'm no longer afraid or anxious about my future well-being.

Kratom has been a literal life saver for me, as I know it has been for many others, and could have been for so many more.

To Whom it May Concern,

My name is Matthew Polk and I am writing this comment in support of the botanical substance known as Kratom (mitragyna speciosa) and to voice my opposition to any attempts to ban or make this plant unavailable to US citizens.

I am a public school teacher in Florida, and I was diagnosed with Generalized Anxiety Disorder in 2014.  I have taken several prescribed medications recommended by my specialists since my diagnosis and have had some success with only one of these medications.  I refused from the very beginning to take benzodiazepines because of the negative side effects of the drug, but I am currently on an SSRI.

I am divulging this information because my support for the kratom plant stems from my experience managing my current condition.  I have been using the kratom plant as a supplementary substance in conjunction with my prescribed medication for more than a year now, and it has helped me tremendously in combating the negative effects of my diagnosed condition.

I am in no way making the statement that kratom (mitragyna speciosa) is medication, as I do not have a medical degree and cannot make recommendations as to how to combat medical conditions.  However, I am stating my anecdotal experiences with the plant so that the governmental agencies that have regularity power over it's availability will reconsider how they plan to regulate the plant.

The plant affects me in several ways.  Firstly, it has painkilling, or analgesic, effects that are mild but effective.  Second, the plant does create a feeling of well-being and euphoria that is nice, gentle, and uplifting.  Thirdly, the plant helps the anxious loops that my brain sometimes gets into (as a result of my GAD) and calms them so that I am able to function to the best of my ability in situations that would normally cause a high level of discomfort.

In the absence of the plant, I find that I have small, inconsequential withdrawal effects that I would describe as being less severe than those of caffeine (which is a widely available and consumed substance in the US).  Nothing about this plant, in my anecdotal opinion, warrants the extreme measures, including banning and scheduling as a schedule 1 controlled substance, that governmental agencies have signaled they wish to pursue.  Not only that, but there is quite a bit of science behind the plant that backs up my anecdotal claims that the plant is useful and relatively harmless (from well-respected, peer-reviewed journals and institutions).

I am of the opinion that kratom should not be banned, nor should it be regulated to a position where it requires doctor approval to purchase and use.  My anecdotal experience with this botanical substance is that it has useful qualities that could be beneficial for consumers, and provides a safe, effective supplement that consumers should have access to if they so choose.  I support regulation that requires the kratom industry to regulate how the substance is packaged, how it is produced, and how it is marketed and sold just as other substances like alcohol, to an extent in some areas, marijuana, and other botanical substances that are regulated and sold all across the United States.  We should focus on education and scientific research, not simply banning the substance, and most certainly not making US citizens criminals for possession (which, as we have seen over the past many decades, has been a destructive and backwards system). I believe that it poses no immediate health risk based on my experiences and do not support any move to ban or schedule the substance.

documents.commentText: I am a 32 year old graphic designer with degrees in graphic design and psychology. I have previously worked as a compounding pharmacy technician and as a chemical dependency counselor intern for adolescent girls. I oppose proposal 81 FR 59929 intending to classify mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine, the active compounds of kratom (Mitragyna speciosa) as a Schedule I substance. This plant is not a recreational substance. It does not produce a "high" and has low potential for abuse. People who use kratom take it as a natural supplement to help maintain a healthy, happy lifestyle. I began taking kratom when a friend suggested I try it to help get through my day. I suffer from major depression and generalized anxiety. Every day I take a 1/4 tsp of White Maeng Da strain kratom with my juice and it gives me confidence and energy to go about my daily routine. Without it, there are some days the depression makes it impossible for me to even leave the house. No prescription medication has been able to control my depression and anxiety. If kratom becomes illegal I most likely will not be able to maintain a full time career as I have lost jobs in the past due to crippling panic attacks. In addition to my own experience, I have read many personal accounts of individuals who claim kratom helped them break addictions to heroin and their abuse of prescription opiates. In the US, more people die of overdose than vehicular accidents and most of those overdose deaths were from abuse of prescription opioids. (see attachment, "Injury2007.pdf") From my personal experience in substance abuse counseling, I have seen what addiction does to people and to their families. It always stems from other problems- depression, abuse, poverty, etc. Our current system of treating addiction is not effective. Either users are expected to quit cold-turkey or they are made to replace one highly addictive substance for another e.g, heroin for methadone. In the midst of the current opioid crisis we need to further investigate any other potential solutions. Kratom shows promise of helping people struggling with addiction to regain control of their lives (see attachment, nihms-51959.pdf) and needs further study. To fully restrict a potential treatment could potentially cost hundreds if not thousands of lives. I understand that the DEA exists to protect the public from harmful substances, but I do not believe kratom to be dangerous and the benefits far outweigh potential risks. While I am absolutely opposed to classifying kratom as a Schedule I substance, I would be open to regulating it to ensure the quality of leaves being imported for consumption.
